  16. #include <string.h>
  17. #include "caml/alloc.h"
  18. #include "caml/bigarray.h"
  19. #include "caml/mlvalues.h"

  21. /* The L64X128 member of the LXM family.  Taken from figure 1 in
  22.    "LXM: Better Splittable Pseudorandom Number Generators
  23.     (and Almost as Fast)" by Guy L. Steele Jr. and Sebastiano Vigna,
  24.     OOPSLA 2021.  */

  26. ‌static const uint64_t M = 0xd1342543de82ef95;

  28. ‌struct LXM_state {
  29.   uint64_t a;            /* per-instance additive parameter (odd) */
  30.   uint64_t s;            /* state of the LCG subgenerator */
  31.   uint64_t x[2];         /* state of the XBG subgenerator (not 0) */
  32. };

  34. /* In OCaml, states are represented as a 1D big array of 64-bit integers */

  36. ‌#define LXM_val(v) ((struct LXM_state *) Caml_ba_data_val(v))

  38. ‌Caml_inline uint64_t rotl(const uint64_t x, int k) {
  39.   return (x << k) | (x >> (64 - k));
  40. }

  42. ‌CAMLprim uint64_t caml_lxm_next_unboxed(value v)
  43. {
  44.   uint64_t z, q0, q1;
  45.   struct LXM_state * st = LXM_val(v);

  47.   /* Combining operation */
  48.   z = st->s + st->x[0];
  49.   /* Mixing function */
  50.   z = (z ^ (z >> 32)) * 0xdaba0b6eb09322e3;
  51.   z = (z ^ (z >> 32)) * 0xdaba0b6eb09322e3;
  52.   z = (z ^ (z >> 32));
  53.   /* LCG update */
  54.   st->s = st->s * M + st->a;
  55.   /* XBG update */
  56.   q0 = st->x[0]; q1 = st->x[1];
  57.   q1 ^= q0;
  58.   q0 = rotl(q0, 24);
  59.   q0 = q0 ^ q1 ^ (q1 << 16);
  60.   q1 = rotl(q1, 37);
  61.   st->x[0] = q0; st->x[1] = q1;
  62.   /* Return result */
  63.   return z;
  64. }

  66. ‌CAMLprim value caml_lxm_next(value v)
  67. {
  68.   return caml_copy_int64(caml_lxm_next_unboxed(v));
  69. }
